That's a great approach! Gradually increasing the distance and intensity will help you build up your endurance and confidence. It's also important to listen to your body and not push yourself too hard, especially if you're just getting back into biking.

Remember to also take into account the terrain, traffic, and weather conditions when planning your route. You might want to start with a route that's mostly flat and has bike lanes or low traffic volumes.

Additionally, consider investing in some bike accessories that can make your commute more comfortable and convenient, such as:

* A waterproof bag or panniers to carry your gear
* A bike lock and chain to secure your bike at work
* A bell or horn to alert pedestrians and other cyclists
* Reflective gear or lights to increase visibility in low-light conditions
* A bike computer or GPS device to track your route and progress

It's also a good idea to check with your employer about bike-friendly facilities at work, such as bike racks, showers, and lockers.

Most importantly, have fun and enjoy the ride! Biking to work can be a great way to clear your mind, get some exercise, and start your day on a positive note.
